review.title: Other Topics You May Also Agree or Disagree: Modeling Inter-Topic Preferences using Tweets and Matrix Factorization
review.abstract: We present in this paper our approach for modeling inter-topic preferences of Twitter users: for example, those who agree with the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) also agree with free trade. This kind of knowledge is useful not only for stance detection across multiple topics but also for various real-world applications including public opinion surveys, electoral predictions, electoral campaigns, and online debates. In order to extract users' preferences on Twitter, we design linguistic patterns in which people agree and disagree about specific topics (e.g., "A is completely wrong"). By applying these linguistic patterns to a collection of tweets, we extract statements agreeing and disagreeing with various topics. Inspired by previous work on item recommendation, we formalize the task of modeling inter-topic preferences as matrix factorization: representing users' preferences as a user-topic matrix and mapping both users and topics onto a latent feature space that abstracts the preferences. Our experimental results demonstrate both that our proposed approach is useful in predicting missing preferences of users and that the latent vector representations of topics successfully encode inter-topic preferences.

sections.heading: 2 Mining Topic Preferences of Users
sections.text: In this section, we describe how we collect statements in which users agree or disagree with various topics on Twitter, which then serve as source data for modeling cross-topic preferences. Formally, we are interested in acquiring a collection of tuples (u, t, v) where: u, u, U is a user; U is the set of all users on Twitter; t, T is a topic; T is the set of all topics; and v, {+ 1, − 1} is + 1 if the user agrees with the topic and − 1 otherwise (i.e. disagreement). During this work, we use a corpus of 35,328,745,115 Japanese tweets (7,340,730 users) crawled from February 6, 2013 to September 30, 2016. We have removed retweets from the corpus.

sections.heading: 2.1 Mining Linguistic Patterns of Agreement and Disagreement

Specifically, when a tweet message matches a linguistic pattern of coincidence (e.g. "t is necessary"), we consider that the author u of the tweet coincides with the topic t. Conversely, a statement of disagreement is identified by linguistic patterns of disagreement (e.g. "t is unacceptable"). To design linguistic patterns, we focus on hashtags that appear in the corpus, which are popular cues for locating subjective statements such as sensations (Davidov et al., 2010), emotions (Qadir and Riloff, 2014), and irony (Van Hee et al, 2016). Hashtags are also useful to find strong supporters and critics, as well as their target topics; for example, # immigrantsWelcome indicates that the author favors immigrants.

Therefore, in this section, we apply matrix factorization (Koren et al., 2009) to predict missing topics, inspired by research on Item recommendations (Bell and Koren, 2007; Dror et al., 2011). sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced a novel approach to modeling cross-topic preferences of users on Twitter. By developing linguistic patterns to identify support and contradiction statements, we extracted users "preferences on various topics from a large collection of tweets. We formalized the task of modeling cross-topic preferences as a matrix factorization that maps both users and topics to a latent trait space that abstracts users" preferences. By our experimental results, we showed that our approach was able to accurately predict missing topic preferences of users (80-94%) and that our latent vector representations of topics cross-topic preferences correctly encode. In our immediate future work, we plan to embed the topic and user vectors to create a cross-topic point detector. It is possible to generalize our work to model heterogeneous signals, such as those that support A and B's interests, and those that are also interested in B's behavior.
